Driver reports unsettling conversation with Justin Baldoni during 'It Ends With Us' production
item.description: Kevin Alexander, Blake Lively’s longtime driver, has provided testimony alleging an uncomfortable and explicit conversation with Justin Baldoni during the filming of 'It Ends With Us.' According to newly unsealed court documents, Alexander claims Baldoni discussed sexual encounters with women in a manner that made Alexander feel uneasy and distracted while driving. Alexander stated that Baldoni’s comments included suggestions that women had 'forced themselves' on him and that he had 'forced himself' on women, which Alexander described as disturbing. This interaction occurred during their first meeting and reportedly prompted Alexander to immediately inform Lively of his discomfort. These allegations appear amid ongoing legal proceedings between Lively and Baldoni. item.title: Allegations of Severe Abuse and Torture at Fort Bliss ICE Detention Facility in Texas
item.description: According to a December 2025 letter by the ACLU of Texas, Human Rights Watch, and other human rights groups, detainees at Fort Bliss, Texas, have reported severe abuse and sexual torture by ICE officers. The facility, also known as Camp East Montana, currently houses over 2,700 people, making it the largest immigration detention center in the United States. Sworn declarations from detainees describe officers crushing testicles, slamming heads into walls, sexual assault, verbal humiliation, and denying access to medical care and lawyers. One teenager, identified as 'Samuel,' described being beaten unconscious, having his tooth broken, and suffering severe testicular and ear injuries. Another detainee, 'Isaac,' reported similar sexual abuse and threats of forced deportation to countries they had no ties to. The tent camp was opened in August 2025 despite warnings of potential humanitarian disaster. Human rights groups argue these abuses violate both U.S. civil and criminal law as well as

item.title: Israeli Soldiers Accused of Abusing Palestinian Detainee Receive Public Support at Court Hearing
item.description:
The article reports on a controversial court hearing in Jerusalem in which two Israeli soldiers accused of sexually assaulting a Palestinian detainee were greeted with applause from supporters inside the courtroom. The soldiers are among five members of an Israeli military unit charged with aggravated assault following an incident at the Sde Teiman detention camp in July 2024. A leaked video from the incident shows soldiers beating a Palestinian prisoner and later gang-raping him behind riot shields. The detainee was hospitalized with severe internal injuries and long-term trauma.
The court hearing did not focus on the alleged assault itself, but rather on a dispute over who should lead the investigation into the leak of the video footage. The leak sparked a major political and institutional scandal in Israel, ultimately leading to the resignation and arrest of the army’s former chief legal adviser, Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi. item.title: Evangeline Lilly discusses the personal and financial challenges of recovering from a traumatic brain injury
item.description:
Evangeline Lilly has opened up about the profound physical, emotional, and financial impact of recovering from a traumatic brain injury sustained after an accident last year. In a video shared on Instagram, the actor described fainting at a beach in May and falling face-first onto a boulder, an incident that resulted in a concussion and later a diagnosis of traumatic brain injury. Since then, she says her cognitive functioning has been noticeably affected, prompting her to seek extensive evaluations and highly specialized treatment.
Lilly explained that her recovery has required significant financial resources, as she pursued expert assessments and customized care tailored specifically to her condition. She was careful to acknowledge that her ability to access such treatment is tied to her financial means, emphasizing that many people do not have the same opportunities when it comes to quality healthcare. Throughout the video, she repeatedly clarified that she is not a medical profess

item.title: Allegations of Abuse and Neglect at ICE Detention Center in Fort Bliss, Texas
item.description: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is under intense scrutiny after reports surfaced of severe mistreatment of migrants at Fort Bliss, Texas. The facility, historically used as a WWII Japanese internment camp, is accused of widespread abuse, including physical beatings, sexual assault, and denial of basic necessities such as food, hygiene supplies, and medical care. A 19-page investigative report supported by the ACLU and Human Rights Watch documents over 80 violations of federal standards, including incidents where detainees were tortured to coerce deportation. Deaths in ICE custody have reached a 20-year high, further escalating concerns. Activists emphasize that detainees are often denied legal representation, restricting their ability to challenge abuse or detention. Conditions at the center include overcrowded tents, exposure to raw sewage, and lack of essential medications. Advocates argue that the facility mirrors the harsh conditions of its WWII-era internment operatio

item.title: Republican leaders demand investigation after federal agents kill Minneapolis protester
item.description:
A fatal shooting in Minneapolis has triggered rare and increasingly public criticism of President Donald Trump and federal law enforcement agencies from within the Republican Party. The incident involved the death of Alex Pretti, an ICU nurse and U.S. citizen who was active in recent protests. According to federal authorities, Pretti was described as a dangerous domestic threat. However, widely shared video footage appears to contradict that claim, showing that he had been disarmed and restrained when federal agents fired multiple shots.
The killing has reignited debate over the conduct, training, and oversight of federal immigration enforcement. Several Republican officials have expressed alarm that the actions of federal agents may have violated constitutional protections and eroded public trust. item.title: Obama Calls for Accountability After Fatal Shootings in Minnesota
item.description: In this article, former President Barack Obama addresses the tragic killing of Alex Pretti and emphasizes that it should serve as a wake-up call for all Americans. He highlights concerns over federal law enforcement and immigration agents acting outside of the law in Minnesota, including tactics perceived as intimidating and dangerous. Obama criticizes the current administration for escalating tensions rather than promoting accountability and collaboration with state and local officials, which could prevent further tragedies. He stresses the importance of lawful, transparent, and cooperative policing, urging officials to work constructively with Governor Walz, Mayor Frey, and local police. Additionally, Obama encourages citizens to support peaceful protests and to actively speak out against injustice, protect fundamental freedoms, and hold the government accountable. The article underscores the responsibility of every American to defend core values and ensure public safety while advoca

item.title: Mount Athos: Historical Monastic Rules on Entry for Women, Animals, and Catalans
item.description: Mount Athos, a remote peninsula in northern Greece, has long been home to Orthodox monks living under strict ascetic traditions. For over a thousand years, it operated as an autonomous monastic republic with its own laws, recognized historically by Byzantine emperors, Ottoman sultans, Greek kings, and even the European Union. A rule called 'avaton', established in 1046, prohibited the entry of women to preserve the monks’ spiritual focus. Female animals were also banned to prevent distractions, although some, like cats and hens, were allowed for practical reasons. Interestingly, Catalans were historically banned due to a violent conflict in 1305 known as the 'Catalan Revenge'. Following the assassination of Roger de Flor and the massacre of Catalan mercenaries, the survivors retaliated brutally against the Byzantine Empire, including looting monasteries on Mount Athos. As a result, Catalans were collectively prohibited from entering the peninsula for centuries. While modern administrat

item.title: Melissa Gilbert issues statement following legal charges against her husband
item.description: Melissa Gilbert has publicly addressed the situation involving her husband, actor Timothy Busfield, following his formal charges related to alleged child sex abuse. In a statement shared via her lifestyle brand Modern Prairie, Gilbert emphasized gratitude, reflection, and emotional resilience during this difficult period. She shared a photograph of herself holding a cup of coffee and wrote about the importance of slowing down, prioritizing what truly matters, and taking moments for rest and self-reflection. Gilbert thanked supporters for their patience and encouragement, noting that their support helped her feel grounded and secure. She also mentioned that she would be gradually returning to her work and online presence, approaching it thoughtfully and cautiously. Busfield surrendered to authorities on January 13 and faces two counts of criminal sexual contact with a minor and one count of child abuse. He was released on January 20 in New Mexico and is awaiting trial. While Gilbert’s s

item.title: How to Crush Ice Elegantly for Cocktails Using a Mallet and Lewis Bag
item.description: This article explores the art of crushing ice for cocktails using traditional tools: a wooden mallet and a Lewis bag. Unlike modern machines or ice dispensers, this method emphasizes a hands-on, tactile experience that transforms large, rigid ice blocks into soft, crushed ice perfect for beverages like mojitos, mint juleps, and whiskey cocktails. The process is described as both therapeutic and ceremonious, allowing drink makers to engage with the ingredients and enhance the overall hospitality experience. By manually breaking down ice, the surface area increases, which not only improves the drink's texture but also its flavor and social appeal. The article highlights the simplicity and charm of the wooden mallet and canvas bag combination, priced at $24.99, presenting it as a small investment for a more enjoyable and elegant cocktail-making ritual. A link discovered by a user on uscardforum.com highlights this increased offer. According to Doctor of Credit, applicants may even receive an additional 5,000 points by applying over the phone with a special promo code. The card provides 100K points plus a 25,000-point global companion award after spending $6,000 in the first 90 days, with a $395 annual fee. item.title: The Intergenerational Wealth Transfer in Spain and Its Economic and Social Consequences
item.description:
The article analyzes the so-called “Great Succession,” the massive intergenerational transfer of wealth that is beginning to take place in Spain as the baby boomer generation passes on its accumulated assets to heirs. Estimated at around four trillion euros and unfolding over the current and next decade, this transfer is described as one of the largest movements of private wealth in Spain’s recent history. Spanish banks view the process as a major business opportunity, competing aggressively to attract the new profile of the ‘millennial heir’: digitally savvy, suddenly wealthy, and potentially loyal to new financial products.
Beyond its immediate financial implications, the article stresses the broader economic and social risks associated with this phenomenon. item.title: The Blue Gemini Program: The US Military’s 1960s Space Capsule Project
item.description: Blue Gemini was a United States Air Force project in the 1960s that aimed to use a modified Gemini spacecraft for military purposes in low Earth orbit. Originally, the Gemini program was a NASA initiative, conceived as Mercury Mark II, to develop orbital docking and extravehicular activities before the Apollo missions. While NASA considered Gemini as a preparatory step toward Apollo, the military saw it as an opportunity to explore space operations for potential orbital stations. In 1962, the Blue Gemini program was launched to support MODS (Manned Orbital Development System), a planned military space station, which later evolved into the MOL (Manned Orbital Laboratory) featuring reconnaissance capabilities including the KH-10 DORIAN telescope. The program planned multiple missions, initially including both NASA and Air Force astronauts, with tasks such as docking with Agena targets, testing the Astronaut Maneuvering Unit, reconnaissance, and deployment of equipment. item.title: Lauren Boebert criticizes Trump's veto of Colorado water bill amid tensions over Epstein files
item.description: In early 2026, tensions grew within the Republican Party as Colorado congresswoman Lauren Boebert publicly criticized President Donald Trump for vetoing a bipartisan water infrastructure bill. The legislation, co-sponsored by Boebert and Republican Jeff Hurd alongside two Democratic senators, aimed to extend loan repayment deadlines for Colorado towns building a crucial water pipeline. The bill had passed unanimously in both chambers of Congress. Trump vetoed it, arguing that it would extend federal taxpayer responsibility for local costs and perpetuate inefficient policies. Boebert condemned the veto as a betrayal of constituents’ needs, noting that it denied clean drinking water to thousands of Coloradans who had supported the president in all three of his elections. She added that she hoped the decision was not political retaliation for her support of a measure demanding the release of the Epstein files. item.title: Tianjin Zhongshuge Bookstore Renovation Blends Historic Bricks with Futuristic Design
item.description: The Tianjin Zhongshuge bookstore renovation addresses a unique architectural challenge: integrating a modern bookstore into Tianjin’s Italian-style district with century-old brick buildings. X+Living’s design emphasizes red brick, using it as the core material for the facade, spiral staircase, book 'rooms,' arches, and circulation elements. Approximately 400,000 custom bricks were hand-cut to create a seamless and immersive experience that feels rooted in the neighborhood while maintaining a futuristic, almost science-fiction aesthetic. In the central space, dark blue steel elements contrast with the brick, inspired by blinds to open sightlines and prevent the masonry from feeling too heavy. Furniture such as shelving, benches, and seating is built as an extension of the architecture, ensuring cohesive visual continuity and avoiding typical retail clutter. item.title: Temporary Display Error Showing 1-Year Expiration for United TravelBank Funds
item.description: Recent reports indicate that funds recently added to United's TravelBank are showing an expiration date of one year from the date of deposit, instead of the standard five years. TravelBank functions like a stored-value account that allows customers to use funds for United flight bookings, and historically, these funds have a five-year validity period. Users who added money to their accounts have noticed the 1-year expiration reflected in their accounts, though the official terms and conditions still state a five-year expiration. United customer support reportedly confirms that this is a likely glitch, and the issue is expected to be corrected in the near future. Travelers are advised to monitor their accounts but not to be overly concerned unless the discrepancy persists for an extended period. This temporary display issue does not appear to affect the actual validity of TravelBank funds.

item.description: Capital One Shopping has rolled out targeted 'Home Page Bonus Offers' available to some users even without a Capital One account. These promotions provide cashback on purchases at various retailers and travel sites. Examples include $250 back on a hotel booking of $250 or more, $100 back on $250 at Trip.com, and $30 back on $50 at Walmart. Availability is highly personalized, with some users seeing significant deals while others see smaller offers or none at all. The bonus offers are displayed in a grey box on the home page, which can be expanded to reveal additional offers. Users can only activate one offer per category, such as one travel offer, making it important to review terms carefully. While some team members at Frequent Miler did not have any offers, others discovered valuable travel and retail cashback opportunities. item.title: Andrew Johnson, pardoned Jan. 6 rioter, faces trial on child molestation charges
item.description: Andrew Johnson, a former participant in the January 6 Capitol riot who was pardoned by former President Donald Trump, is scheduled for a criminal trial on child molestation charges in Florida. Johnson, 44, allegedly abused a victim over several months beginning in 2024 in Hernando County. Court filings indicate that he attempted to silence the victim by offering a financial payout and referencing his Trump pardon, claiming he would include the victim in his will. Previously, Johnson pleaded guilty to four federal charges related to the Capitol riot, including breaking into a Senate meeting room and menacing police, and was sentenced to one year in prison in August 2024, a sentence later wiped out by the pardon. He was arrested in July 2025 and remains in custody ahead of his trial scheduled for February 9, 2026. Johnson has pleaded not guilty. item.title: Israel erased more than 2,700 Palestinian family bloodlines in the Gaza genocide
item.description: The video presents a claim that Israel has erased over 2,700 Palestinian family bloodlines during the ongoing conflict in Gaza. It alleges a systematic effort to eliminate family lineages, framing the situation as genocide. The video likely uses this claim to underscore the devastating impact of the conflict on Palestinian families and their heritage, while presenting a highly charged narrative.

item.title: Roser Gari denounces the political repression of pro-Palestinian activism in Germany
item.description: Spanish activist Roser Gari, currently residing in Berlin, has documented what she describes as systematic political repression against pro-Palestinian activists in Germany. Through her work with the group Palestine on Trial, Gari estimates that since October 2023 there have been around 11,000 trials connected to pro-Palestinian protests. She reports that these judicial processes aim to demoralize and financially exhaust activists, forcing many to abandon their movements due to stress, legal costs, and fear of criminal records that can jeopardize visas, scholarships, or jobs. According to Gari, accusations of 'assaulting police' frequently target those who were in fact victims of police violence, while acts such as chanting banned slogans, wearing Palestinian symbols, or even defending oneself during arrests are treated as criminal offenses. item.title: Comprehensive Library of File Format Specifications Using Kaitai Struct
item.description: The Kaitai Struct Format Gallery serves as an extensive repository of file format specifications defined in the Kaitai Struct language. Each specification provides a formal description of how a given file type is structured, enabling programmers and analysts to work with binary files more effectively. These specifications can be directly used as precise text references, visualized as block diagrams using Graphviz, or employed to explore binary data in hex dumps interactively. Moreover, they can be compiled into ready-to-use libraries across multiple programming languages using the Kaitai Struct compiler. The gallery includes an impressive range of categories, from 3D model formats such as glTF and Quake models to Android-specific images and bootloaders, a variety of archive formats like ZIP, RAR, and RPM, database formats including SQLite and DBF, as well as operating-system–specific structures for DOS, Linux, macOS, and Windows. item.title: The Role of OS Maps in Effective Planning and Development Projects
item.description: Accurate geographic information is essential for successful planning and development projects. OS maps provide planners and developers with a detailed understanding of a site's location, surroundings, topography, boundaries, and environmental features, enabling informed decision-making from the early stages. These maps allow professionals to visualize constraints, assess feasibility, and comply with regulations, reducing costly errors and rework. They also facilitate stakeholder collaboration by offering a common visual reference for engineers, surveyors, and architects, which minimizes misunderstandings. Mapping data supports evidence-based decisions, helps navigate planning regulations, and identifies environmental considerations such as watercourses, drainage, biodiversity, and elevation. Beyond initial planning, OS maps aid in long-term project management, utility coordination, and adaptation to changing project needs, ensuring developments remain practical and sustainable. By rely

item.title: China Investigates Top General Over Nuclear Leak and Bribery Allegations
item.description: China's Ministry of National Defense has launched an investigation into Gen. Zhang Youxia, the country's highest-ranking military officer and a close ally of President Xi Jinping. Authorities allege that Zhang disclosed sensitive details about China's nuclear weapons program to the United States during a high-level briefing attended by senior military leaders. The accusations also include accepting bribes for official actions, such as promoting an officer named Gu to the position of defense minister. This probe follows a surprise announcement on Saturday, highlighting serious breaches of party discipline and state law. Zhang, aged 75, was once seen as Xi's most trusted military figure, making his potential downfall significant for China's leadership stability. The briefing linked Zhang to a security breach in the nuclear sector stemming from the investigation into Gu, though specific details of the leaked information remain undisclosed. item.title: How the U.S. Economic Crisis Is Reshaping Its Military Strategy
item.description:
The article discusses how the United States, under Donald Trump’s second administration, has adjusted its military strategy in response to an ongoing economic crisis. According to the piece, Washington is moving away from overextended global commitments and focusing instead on self-preservation and cost efficiency. The new U.S. national defense policy, presented by the Pentagon, signals a shift in how the country relates to its traditional allies, pressing them to take on greater responsibility for their own defense. This adjustment comes as the U.S. faces internal challenges and a new global balance of power that limits its capacity to act as the world’s primary security guarantor.
In practice, this strategy involves cuts to certain aid programs, relocating military bases, adjusting joint exercises, and tightening budgets. item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Warns Against Political Polarization After Minnesota Shooting
item.description:
Former Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) spoke out following a controversial incident in Minnesota where a federal immigration agent fatally shot a man named Alex Pretti. Greene expressed her support for law enforcement and immigration control but emphasized her defense of the Second Amendment, stating that legally carrying a firearm does not equate to brandishing one. She also underscored the importance of First and Fourth Amendment rights, particularly the rights to protest peacefully and record public events.
In her comments posted on X, Greene urged supporters of former President Donald Trump to imagine how they might respond if similar events occurred under a Democratic administration. She drew parallels between the Minnesota shooting and how the FBI handled January 6 rioters, arguing that the public often interprets law enforcement actions based on partisan lines. Greene warned that such divisions are fueling hostility and could push the nation toward civil conflict.

item.title: NATO Chief Rutte: Europe Depends on US for Defense Against Global Threats
item.description: NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte emphasized to the European Parliament that Europe cannot effectively defend itself without the support of the United States. Rutte stated bluntly that anyone believing the European Union or Europe as a whole can manage its defense independently is 'dreaming.' His remarks come shortly after U.S. President Donald Trump lifted tariffs on the EU and reached preliminary agreements with NATO regarding Greenland. Rutte explained that two workstreams were agreed upon with the U.S. to address tensions and strategic concerns in Greenland. The first involves NATO taking a larger role in Arctic defense to collectively counter the influence of Russia and China. The second workstream is a trilateral discussion between the U.S., Denmark, and Greenland, which NATO will not be part of. item.title: The Persistent Challenges and Limits of Self-Driving Car Technology
item.description:
The article by Yarrow Bouchard argues that fully autonomous driving remains far from being solved, despite notable progress by companies like Waymo and Tesla. It draws heavily on insights from Andrej Karpathy, former Tesla AI lead, who describes the 'march of nines'—each increment in reliability requiring enormous additional effort. Karpathy cautions that while demos may impress, turning them into safe, scalable products takes years due to the immense complexity and high cost of failure. The piece highlights that most major players in the self-driving industry, including Cruise, Uber, Aurora, Apple, and others, have either folded, pivoted, or scaled back their ambitions, suggesting widespread recognition that autonomy remains an unsolved technological and economic challenge.

item.title: The Decline of Sonic Diversity in Natural Environments and Its Ecological and Cultural Implications
item.description: The article explores the ongoing loss of sonic diversity across the planet, describing how the rich variety of natural sounds—from birdsong and frog calls to whale songs and insect choruses—is diminishing due to multiple human-induced factors. Habitat destruction, such as the conversion of diverse forests into monoculture plantations or agricultural fields, results in acoustically impoverished environments with reduced layers of frequencies, melodies, and temporal patterns. Species extinctions have permanently silenced unique voices, including those of the Kauaʻi ʻōʻō bird and Rabbs’ fringe-limbed treefrog, while massive declines in populations of vocal marine species like whales and fish (e.g., over 99% drop in some cod populations and the killing of millions of whales in the 20th century) have erased distinctive aquatic soundscapes, replaced by industrial noises from ships and seismic activities. item.title: Amber Heard Reflects on Public Silence and Return to Acting with 'Silenced'
item.description: After several years away from the public eye, actress Amber Heard has reemerged with a new perspective and focus. Following her relocation to Spain after the widely televised defamation trial between her and Johnny Depp, Heard largely withdrew from public life to care for her three children — twins Agnes and Ocean, and her eldest, Oonagh. Her long silence sparked curiosity, as she had been under intense scrutiny throughout and after the legal proceedings that concluded with her ordered to pay Depp one million dollars in damages, which he later donated to charity. Heard’s public return took place at the 2026 Sundance Film Festival with the premiere of 'Silenced,' directed by Selina Miles. The film explores how women who speak out publicly are often discredited or punished, framing such experiences as part of a broader global issue. item.title: Florida's Tourism Sector Suffers Major Decline Due to Reduced Canadian Visitors Amid U.S.-Canada Tensions
item.description: Florida is facing a significant downturn in its tourism industry, primarily driven by a sharp drop in Canadian visitors, who historically contributed between $38 billion and $42 billion annually to the state's economy. Following escalations in U.S.-Canada trade disputes, including tariff threats on Canadian goods like aluminum, lumber, and agriculture, combined with provocative political statements—such as suggestions of Canada becoming the 51st U.S. state—many Canadians have chosen to avoid travel to Florida and other U.S. destinations. This shift has led to a reported loss of around 280,000 tourism-related jobs in Florida, encompassing roles in hospitality, restaurants, real estate, and support services, with some estimates suggesting the figure could be higher when including indirect impacts. item.description: Costco is offering a discounted $100 inKind gift card for $64.99 through its website, available from January 26, 2026, through February 22, 2026, with a limit of five per membership. inKind is a digital payment app that allows users to pay restaurant bills directly within the app, bypassing the need to use a credit card at the table. item.title: Saks Bankruptcy Impacts Gift Cards, Amex Redemption Trends, and Alex Honnold’s Daring Taipei 101 Climb
item.description:
This article from Frequent Miler’s 'Saturday Selection' highlights three notable stories of the week. First, Saks Global, the parent company of Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus, has filed for bankruptcy, raising concerns about the status of Saks gift cards. A judge has ruled that the retailer may continue honoring its gift cards without violating bankruptcy law, and Saks has confirmed its intention to do so. However, customers remain uneasy about holding gift cards from a bankrupt company. If Saks eventually decides to halt the program, a two-week notice must be provided before termination.
The second topic examines findings from an American Express infographic that revealed the top three Membership Rewards redemption categories among cardholders: gift cards, points used at checkout, and statement credits. item.title: Global Decline in Youth Happiness Linked to Reduced Social Connections, Meaning, and Religious Participation
item.description: Recent studies, including the World Happiness Report and the comprehensive Global Flourishing Study surveying over 200,000 people across 22 countries, reveal a significant drop in happiness among young adults under 30, particularly in wealthy industrialized nations like the United States. Traditionally, self-reported happiness follows a U-shaped curve, with higher levels in youth and older age and a dip in middle adulthood. However, newer data shows that young people's flourishing scores now start low due to rising mood disorders and remain depressed until middle age, altering the classic pattern. This trend is global but more pronounced in affluent, secular societies. Key factors include declining religious attendance, which boosts flourishing measures by about 8% on average worldwide and even more in rich countries, and a corresponding loss of meaning and purpose—ironically, higher GDP per capita correlates with weaker senses of life's worthwhileness. item.title: Designers Explore the Meaning of Home Through 75 Experimental Birdhouses at MAD Brussels
item.description:
The Home Sweet Home exhibition at MAD Brussels offers a thoughtful and imaginative exploration of what it means to belong, using an unexpected medium: the birdhouse. Curated by Connie Hüsser, the exhibition brings together the work of more than 75 designers who were invited to rethink the concept of home on a miniature scale. Rather than functioning purely as shelters for birds, the resulting designs act as small but powerful reflections on architecture, identity, and emotional attachment to place.
The birdhouses vary widely in style and intention. Some resemble traditional cabins or modernist dwellings, while others embrace fantasy, humor, fragility, or nostalgia. This diversity underscores the exhibition’s central idea: that home is not defined by a single form, aesthetic, or size, but by feeling, care, and imagination. item.description: In the Italian Alps near Ponte di Legno, Peter Pichler Architecture has designed a series of new mountain stations and an alpine hut for the Valbione gondola route. These structures replace older ski lifts, providing a smoother and more integrated ascent through the historic alpine landscape. The design draws inspiration from traditional alpine huts, featuring steep gabled roofs, timber construction, and minimalist forms that blend seamlessly with the surrounding terrain without dominating it. item.title: Dutch Parliament Moves Toward Annual Capital Gains Tax by 2028
item.description: The Dutch government is preparing to overhaul its wealth tax system, with plans to begin taxing capital gains annually by 2028. A parliamentary majority appears ready to support the proposal, although many lawmakers criticize its complexity and potential impact on investors. The reform targets the so-called Box 3 asset tax, which had been based on assumed returns rather than actual investment performance — a system the courts ruled unfair. Under the new model, investors would pay tax on both realized and unrealized gains, meaning profits from stocks, bonds, or cryptocurrencies would be taxed even before assets are sold. This approach has sparked concern across the political spectrum, as many parties consider it unreasonable to tax theoretical, non-liquid earnings. Her husband, Brandon Paul, announced the news in an emotional 10-minute Facebook video, where he tearfully described his profound grief while expressing relief that she was no longer in pain. Brandon highlighted their marriage of over two and a half years, calling her his rock, best friend, and the strongest person he knew. item.title: Tree-ring study shows rising precipitation extremes in the western Mediterranean over the last five centuries
item.description: This research, published in *Climate of the Past* by Marcos Marín-Martín and colleagues, reconstructs 520 years of precipitation variability in eastern Spain using tree-ring data from *Pinus sylvestris* and *Pinus nigra*. The study area, located in the Iberian Range of Aragón, provides one of the longest and most detailed regional hydroclimatic records for the western Mediterranean. The authors developed a robust tree-ring chronology and correlated it with high-resolution precipitation datasets, achieving a strong relationship between annual ring growth and rainfall over a 320-day window from August to June. Their reconstruction shows substantial long-term variation in precipitation patterns since 1505 CE and, notably, a distinct intensification of both droughts and wet extremes since the late twentieth century. item.description: In Spain, every square centimeter of land belongs to a municipality, a system rooted in the 1833 territorial organization by Javier de Burgos. item.title: Record Numbers of Ladybirds in the UK in 2025 Due to Favourable Weather and Abundant Food Sources
item.description: In 2025, the UK has experienced an exceptional surge in ladybird populations, with these beloved beetles appearing in record numbers across gardens, homes, and even disrupting events like a cricket match at Lord's. Experts, including Professor Helen Roy from the UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology and the University of Exeter, attribute this boom to several favourable conditions. A mild winter allowed many ladybirds to emerge successfully from hibernation, followed by a dry spring that produced high numbers of aphids—the primary food source for many ladybird species. Subsequent warm, humid summer weather and heatwaves enabled the new generation to thrive, complete their life cycles quickly, and multiply rapidly. While some sightings involve the invasive harlequin ladybird, which tends to cluster in large groups indoors or on structures, most are harmless native species like the seven-spot ladybird. item.title: Lazerian’s 'Cathedral of Sound' Turns Donated Guitars into a Living Musical Sculpture in Manchester
item.description:
The 'Cathedral of Sound' is a large-scale public art installation created by Liam Hopkins of Manchester’s creative studio Lazerian. It embodies the deep connection between the city and its musical heritage. Built from hundreds of donated guitars collected through a citywide Guitar Amnesty, the work transforms these instruments—some pristine, others worn or broken—into a striking wooden pavilion that resonates with the collective memory of Manchester’s music scene. The sculpture goes beyond symbolism: it actively produces sound. A wind-activated system plucks the embedded guitar strings, allowing the structure to play itself in response to changes in the weather. Thus, the artwork becomes a living instrument, performing an ever-shifting symphony of subtle tones.

The photos were taken in remote areas including Crater Lake in Oregon, Mount Baker, and California’s Bristlecone pine forests. Each picture represents hours of preparation, patience, and technical precision. Working through long, cold nights, Johnson adjusts his camera settings in total darkness using long exposures to gather as much starlight as possible. item.description:

K. had claimed 'combatant privilege,' arguing that his alleged actions were those of a Ukrainian soldier targeting enemy infrastructure amid war with Russia. The BGH ruled that this argument does not apply because the Nord Stream pipelines are considered civilian infrastructure and that covert operations without clear state affiliation, such as uniforms or formal orders, are excluded from combatant immunity under international law.
The court confirmed that Serhii K. will face prosecution in Germany for violating the country’s internal security and sovereignty. item.title: Practical Strategies for Managing and Overcoming Depression
item.description: Depression often feels permanent and personal, convincing individuals that something is inherently wrong with them and that change is impossible. However, it is a temporary state rather than a character flaw, and recovery involves gradual, realistic steps rather than sudden fixes. Key hurdles include low energy and motivation; the article emphasizes starting with small actions—like getting out of bed, opening a window, or completing one task—because waiting for motivation rarely works, and even minor progress can weaken depression's hold. Cognitively, depression distorts neutral events into personal failures, so gently questioning these thoughts—distinguishing facts from feelings—and considering positive overthinking can help. Isolation worsens the condition, making connection vital, even through low-effort interactions like sharing a laugh or sending a message, as human contact counters the brain's insistence on loneliness. item.title: The Ongoing Scientific Challenges in Understanding Consciousness
item.description: The article explores why consciousness remains one of science's most elusive mysteries, tracing its potential evolutionary origins to the Cambrian explosion when complex brains enabled unified sensory experiences, emotions, and self-awareness. It highlights the shift from philosophical dualism to materialism and the field's revival in the 1990s through pioneers like Francis Crick and Christof Koch, who used tools like fMRI to seek neural correlates of consciousness via experiments on visual illusions and binocular rivalry. Despite decades of progress, including maps of brain networks active during awareness and tools to detect consciousness in impaired patients, no consensus exists on its definition or mechanisms. Key theories include global neuronal workspace (GNWT), higher-order theories, predictive processing, and integrated information theory (IIT), which posits consciousness arises from complex, integrated information and even suggests panpsychist implications. item.title: Braided vs. Silicone Cables: Durability and Performance Comparison
item.description: Choosing the right cable material – whether it’s braided or silicone – significantly impacts its durability and performance. Braided cables, often constructed from woven nylon or polyester, are known for their longevity and resistance to fraying and bending. The textured weave provides a firm grip and prevents tangling, making them ideal for travel and demanding work environments. Magnetic charging solutions, such as those offered by Statik, often leverage this design to enhance exterior strength without adding excessive weight. In contrast, silicone cables offer exceptional flexibility and heat resistance, remaining soft even in cold temperatures and minimizing the risk of kinking. item.description: The shift from paper-based to digital evidence has transformed legal operations, litigation, and compliance. Today, legal teams handle vast amounts of information spread across emails, chat histories, cloud files, and shared drives rather than neatly organized paper documents. These tools also support accurate timelines, reduce manual work, and alleviate stress when facing tight deadlines. item.description: The quality of raw, unroasted coffee beans plays a fundamental role in the taste, aroma, and overall enjoyment of the final brewed cup, far beyond the brewing method itself. For example, beans from higher altitudes often develop more complex and vibrant flavor profiles with bright acidity and fruity or floral notes, while Arabica varieties generally offer smoother, more nuanced tastes compared to the stronger, more bitter Robusta. item.title: Construction Begins on Bishoftu International Airport, Set to Become Africa's Largest Aviation Hub
item.description: Construction has officially started on Bishoftu International Airport (BIA), a major infrastructure project located about 40 kilometers southeast of Ethiopia's capital, Addis Ababa. Designed by the renowned firm Zaha Hadid Architects for Ethiopian Airlines Group, the airport aims to serve as the country's primary international gateway and position Ethiopia as a key aviation connector linking Africa with Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. Upon full completion, BIA is projected to handle up to 110 million passengers per year, making it the highest-capacity airport on the African continent. The initial phase, targeted for opening around 2030, will accommodate approximately 60 million passengers annually, featuring two runways and a large terminal. The design prioritizes efficiency, passenger comfort, and cultural relevance, incorporating a central organizational spine to streamline transfers, integrated gardens, outdoor courtyards, and a 350-room airside hotel for rest amid high traffic.

item.title: Spotify and Major Labels Secure US Court Order to Suspend Anna’s Archive Domains Over Alleged Spotify Scraping
item.description: Shadow library Anna’s Archive, known for hosting pirated books and other media, recently scraped approximately 300TB of data from Spotify, including metadata, audio analysis, and cover art for millions of tracks, with plans to potentially release audio files. In late December 2025, Spotify, Sony, Warner, and Universal Music Group filed a sealed lawsuit in the US District Court for the Southern District of New York accusing the site of copyright infringement. On January 2, 2026, a judge granted an ex parte temporary restraining order directing domain registry Public Interest Registry (PIR) and Cloudflare to disable access to Anna’s Archive domains to prevent further distribution of copyrighted material. Anna’s Archive was not notified until after implementation, as plaintiffs feared preemptive release of the scraped songs or infrastructure relocation. item.description: A recent study led by Aida Fiz López, published in Clinical and Experimental Immunology, investigated why many adult celiac disease patients continue to show intestinal mucosal damage despite years of strict gluten-free diet adherence. The research analyzed duodenal biopsies from 19 celiac patients (average 7 years on diet), compared to newly diagnosed patients and healthy controls, using advanced spectral cytometry to examine 72 immune cell populations. Results revealed that 68.4% of patients on the diet still had persistent villous atrophy. Notably, only one patient showed gluten traces in feces, confirming good dietary compliance in the others, and most had negative serology (antibodies). item.description: Bamboo shoots, long a staple in Asian cuisines through stir-fries, soups, and fermented preparations, are gaining scientific attention as a potentially nutrient-dense food. Key findings indicate that bamboo shoots are rich in dietary fiber, such as cellulose and lignin, which supports digestion, gut health, regularity, and possibly beneficial gut bacteria. Early human studies suggest benefits for metabolic health, including better blood sugar regulation and improved cholesterol levels, which could lower risks for diabetes and heart disease. Her series, part of the ongoing project 'Miracles in Gardens,' reimagines flowers not simply as botanical subjects but as poetic expressions of balance, precision, and depth. Each bloom is photographed against a deep black background, allowing petals and textures to emerge from shadow with an almost sculptural presence. The use of reflected or symmetrical compositions enhances the sense of harmony and order, while the subdued color palette and moody lighting evoke quiet emotion. Babecova’s approach emphasizes the organic geometry of each plant, bringing attention to subtle variations in form and tone. The result is a collection that feels both natural and meticulously composed, inviting viewers to perceive flowers as mysterious and powerful symbols of life and decay. item.title: Global Boycotts and War Disrupt Israeli Agricultural Export Industry
item.description:
The article explores the severe crisis facing Israel’s agricultural export sector as international markets increasingly reject Israeli produce in response to the war in Gaza. Drawing on reports from Israel’s public broadcaster Kan 11, journalist Jonathan Ofir describes how fruit growers, particularly those producing citrus and mangoes, warn of a potential collapse. European buyers are avoiding Israeli fruits, while the Houthi blockade in the Red Sea has caused major shipping disruptions to Asian markets. Together, these pressures have left Russia as one of the few remaining destinations for Israeli produce — creating what one farmer calls an 'alliance of the boycotted.'
The report highlights the rapid decline of once-iconic exports like Jaffa oranges, emblematic of Israel’s agricultural brand, which also carries a history of cultural appropriation from Palestinian farming traditions. item.description: The 'prosperity plan,' an anticipated economic package worth around $800 billion for Ukraine's postwar reconstruction and including security guarantees, was expected to see progress or a potential announcement during the 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos. However, escalating tensions between the US and European allies over President Donald Trump's aggressive push to acquire Greenland—accompanied by tariff threats against Denmark and other NATO members—shifted the focus away from Ukraine-related agreements. According to reports from Axios and the Financial Times, the dispute overshadowed preparations, leading to the postponement of any formal signing or major announcement involving Trump, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, and European leaders. US officials emphasized that no specific date had been fixed and that the plan required further refinements. item.title: Democrats Urge Invocation of 25th Amendment Over Trump's Greenland Acquisition Push
item.description: Several Democratic politicians, including Representatives Sydney Kamlager-Dove, Yassamin Ansari, Eric Swalwell, and Senator Ed Markey, have publicly called for invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to remove President Donald Trump from office. This stems from his escalating efforts to acquire Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark, which he claims is essential for U.S. national security in the Arctic. Trump has refused to rule out military force and recently sent a letter to Norwegian Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre, stating he 'no longer feel[s] an obligation to think purely of Peace' after not receiving the Nobel Peace Prize in 2025, which was awarded to Venezuela's opposition leader María Corina Machado. Critics link this to perceived instability, with some describing Trump as 'unfit to lead,' 'out of control,' or 'extremely mentally ill.' item.description: Capital One has improved the welcome offer for the Venture Rewards Credit Card, effective as of January 20, 2026. New cardholders can now earn 75,000 bonus miles after spending $4,000 on purchases within the first three months of account opening. In addition, upon approval, they receive a one-time $250 Capital One Travel credit, usable for bookings such as flights, hotels, car rentals, vacation rentals, or activities through the Capital One Travel portal within the first 12 months. This credit is flexible—it can be applied to one or multiple purchases, does not earn rewards, and is restored (if not expired) upon cancellation of a booking. The card carries a $95 annual fee and earns 2X miles on all purchases, with 5X miles on hotels, vacation rentals, rental cars booked via Capital One Travel, and Capital One Entertainment. item.title: Review of the Westin Bora Bora Resort & Spa: Stunning Views and Good Points Value with Some Drawbacks
item.description: The Westin Bora Bora Resort & Spa, recently refurbished and rebranded from Le Méridien, offers a modern and fresh experience compared to neighboring properties like the St. Regis. The resort boasts exceptional views of Mount Otemanu, particularly from Premium Otemanu View overwater bungalows with plunge pools, which the reviewer described as one of their all-time favorite rooms. Standard overwater bungalows can often be booked using Marriott Bonvoy points (around 71,000–77,500 per night) or 85K free night certificates, providing excellent value far exceeding typical valuations for Marriott redemptions. The grounds feel brand new, with complimentary amenities like clear-bottomed kayaks and paddle boards. item.title: Davos Protests Escalate as Trump Defends Greenland Pursuit
item.description: Widespread protests have erupted in Switzerland and Greenland as US President Donald Trump prepares to attend the World Economic Forum in Davos. Demonstrations included the burning of American flags and projections of satirical images onto ski slopes, reflecting growing anger over Trump's persistent attempts to purchase Greenland. Violent clashes between protesters and police in Zurich resulted in property damage and the use of water cannons, chemical irritants, and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. The situation has escalated Trump's public spats with European leaders, with Ursula von der Leyen criticizing his tariffs threats and highlighting Europe’s Arctic policing capabilities. The president has doubled down on his Greenland ambitions, threatening tariffs and ruling out backtracking. item.title: Gavin Newsom Criticizes World Leaders for Yielding to Trump's Greenland Demands and Tariff Threats at Davos
item.description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos on January 20, 2026, California Governor Gavin Newsom sharply criticized global leaders, particularly Europeans, for what he described as excessive compliance toward U.S. President Donald Trump. Newsom remarked that leaders were 'rolling over' and quipped he should have brought kneepads for them, calling their behavior 'pathetic' and 'embarrassing.' He referenced Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado's symbolic regifting of her Nobel Peace Prize to Trump as an example. Newsom urged European lawmakers to 'stop being complicit,' 'have a backbone,' and stand united rather than allowing Trump to 'play folks for fools.' He likened Trump to a 'T-Rex,' stating one must either 'mate with him or he devours you.' item.title: Seletti Launches Oversized Bic Cristal Pen Lamp to Mark 75th Anniversary
item.description: The article highlights a whimsical and eye-catching design collaboration between Italian brand Seletti and designer Mario Paroli: an oversized lamp inspired by the iconic Bic Cristal ballpoint pen. To commemorate the pen's 75th anniversary since its debut in France in 1950, the everyday object has been dramatically enlarged to 12 times its original size, transforming it into a bold statement lighting piece. The lamp replaces the ink cartridge with a sleek linear LED element that provides illumination, adding both functionality and a playful, nostalgic touch to interior spaces. Available in the classic Bic colors—red, black, and blue—it can function as a pendant, wall-mounted, or floor lamp, evoking humor through its absurdist scale while celebrating the pen's status as the world's best-selling writing instrument, with over 100 billion units sold. item.title: Davos 2026: Shifting AI from Experimental Pilots to Measurable Productivity Amid Labor Disruptions and Geopolitical Tensions
item.description: The 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos highlighted that artificial intelligence (AI) has moved beyond hype but still struggles to deliver widespread economic value. Business leaders expressed frustration with perpetual pilot projects that fail to scale due to poor data quality, undefined processes, and weak governance. Experts like PwC's Mohamed Kande emphasized the need for top-down strategies focusing on high-impact use cases that directly affect revenue, costs, or customer experience, integrating AI into core business operations with clear productivity metrics. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella warned that if AI benefits remain concentrated in big tech, it risks becoming a bubble rather than a productive revolution, stressing democratization for gains in health, education, public sectors, and SMEs. item.title: RiverView Ranch Retreat in Montana offers rare Hilton points availability for luxury all-inclusive stays
item.description:
The article highlights a notable opportunity to book the ultra-luxurious RiverView Ranch Retreat & Western Adventures in Montana using Hilton Honors points. This property, part of the Small Luxury Hotels of the World collection, is fully all-inclusive and known for its outstanding personalized service. Award stays are priced at 220,000 Hilton points per night, with a fifth night free for members with Silver status or higher — costing 880,000 points for a five-night stay. The retreat provides a rare combination of exclusivity and exceptional value for points, as cash rates can exceed $4,000 per night.
The author emphasizes that availability for consecutive nights, often scarce at high-end properties, is currently strong from late September through mid-November 2026. item.description: The article explores the possibility that Greenland's autonomous government could pursue direct negotiations with the United States for annexation or a close association, sidelining Denmark amid alleged US influence operations and meetings with local politicians since last year. It highlights Greenland's strategic value, rooted in WWII-era bases for Atlantic protection and Arctic weather intelligence, and post-war US military presence via agreements. Denmark is portrayed as a colonial power that has gradually granted autonomy, including a 31-seat parliament (Inatsisartut) and EU exit in 1985. The political scene features five parties: the pro-Denmark Democratic Party (10 seats), nationalist Naleraq (8 seats, fast independence), ecosocialist Inuit Ataqatigiit (7 seats, gradual independence), center-left Siumut, and conservative unionist Atassut (2 seats). item.title: EU Faces Rising Strategic Vulnerability from Increasing Dependence on US LNG Imports Amid Transatlantic Tensions
item.description: The European Union is rapidly increasing its reliance on liquefied natural gas (LNG) from the United States, with imports already accounting for about 27 percent of the bloc's total gas supplies, up from just 5 percent in 2021. This shift occurred as the EU drastically reduced Russian gas imports following the 2022 invasion of Ukraine, dropping from 50 percent to 12 percent, with a full ban on Russian gas phased in. Projections indicate that by 2030, nearly half of the EU's gas could come from the US, representing up to 80 percent of its LNG imports, according to data from the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA). This growing dependency creates a significant geopolitical risk, especially as transatlantic relations deteriorate under US President Donald Trump. item.title: The EU introduces new cybersecurity rules restricting Chinese telecom firms
item.description:
The European Commission has unveiled a new cybersecurity regulation that bans Chinese companies from operating telecom networks within the EU. Henna Virkkunen, European Vice President for Technological Sovereignty, announced the measure after voluntary recommendations to limit 'high-risk' providers failed to yield consistent results across member states. The rule will legally oblige EU countries to exclude these companies—particularly Chinese firms involved in 5G networks—within three years, at an estimated cost between 3 and 4 billion euros. The regulation forms part of a broader initiative aimed at securing the information and communication technology supply chain across 18 critical sectors, including energy, transport, healthcare, cloud services, and semiconductors.

item.title: Tana Ramsay opens up about her struggle with melasma and skin health awareness
item.description:
Tana Ramsay, wife of celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay, recently spoke candidly about her experience with melasma — a common skin condition that causes dark or discolored patches on the face. In an interview with The Times, the 51-year-old shared that her skin issues were linked to long periods of sun exposure, explaining that she and her husband 'used to bake' in the sun before realizing the long-term effects. Melasma, according to the Cleveland Clinic, is often aggravated by UV exposure or tanning beds and can appear as brown or gray spots that sometimes itch or irritate the skin.
Tana recalled a moment when a pharmacist asked about the stains on her face, which made her more conscious of sun protection. She now takes precautions daily and never goes out without sunscreen. Her discussion of skin health follows her husband’s own recent health scare. item.title: Mexico Launches Unified Health Credential and Electronic Medical Record System for Universal Public Healthcare Access
item.description:
The Mexican government, under President Claudia Sheinbaum, has initiated a nationwide process to issue a single Credential for the Universal Health Service, starting in March 2026. This credential, available in both physical and digital formats (via a mobile app from April), aims to unify access to public healthcare services across federal institutions including IMSS, ISSSTE, IMSS-Bienestar, national health institutes, Pemex medical services, and Armed Forces facilities. It eliminates barriers based on prior institutional affiliation or residence, allowing any individual to receive care anywhere in the public network.
The physical card includes personal details such as full name, CURP, sex, birth information, nationality, blood type, organ donation willingness, emergency contacts, and two QR codes: one for validating eligibility and assigned institution/clinic, and another for locating the nearest health unit. item.description:
This comprehensive guide from Frequent Miler outlines the policies of major hotel loyalty programs regarding the gifting or sharing of points, free night certificates, and the booking of award nights for family members or friends. For Choice Privileges, points transfers or pooling will become possible later in 2026 at no cost, though details remain pending. Hilton Honors permits free points transfers and pooling with up to 10 members, with annual limits and activity requirements. IHG One Rewards charges $5 per 1,000 points for transfers, but free transfers are available to Diamond members (up to 100,000 points/year) or via IHG Business Rewards under specific conditions. Marriott Bonvoy allows free transfers of up to 100,000 points per year, with online processing now available. World of Hyatt permits point transfers but restricts them to once every 30 days, handled via email submission.

item.title: Blending Modernity and Tradition in Korean and Japanese Cities: Seoul, Busan, Kyoto, Osaka, and Kanazawa
item.description: Cities in South Korea and Japan masterfully integrate rapid modernization with deep-rooted cultural heritage, creating vibrant urban environments where history coexists seamlessly with contemporary life. In Seoul, towering glass skyscrapers and efficient subways stand alongside traditional hanok houses, serene courtyards, and historic sites like Gyeongbokgung Palace, which remains a lively hub for locals and visitors alike. Busan offers a contrasting coastal vibe, framed by mountains and the sea, with bustling markets, fresh seafood stalls, cliffside temples, and beaches shaping its identity. The high-speed train journey from Seoul to Busan reveals Korea's diverse landscapes in just a few hours. In Japan, Kyoto embodies tranquility with its preserved temples, bamboo groves, and walkable historic districts that maintain traditional rhythms. item.description: A recent article from Frequent Miler highlights several active, targeted card-linked offers that provide discounts on bookings through Turo, the peer-to-peer car-sharing platform. These promotions are available depending on the user's specific credit card accounts and can be activated through the respective banks' offer portals. The Amex Offer provides 20% back on up to $150 in spending, resulting in a maximum $30 statement credit for a single qualifying purchase of car rentals made directly at turo.com or via the Turo app, with an expiration date of March 31, 2026. item.title: Iowa Trump Voters Express Frustration with Administration's Direction, Considering Democratic Votes in 2026 Midterms
item.description: A year into President Donald Trump's second term, some voters in Iowa who supported him in the 2024 election are showing signs of dissatisfaction and 'exhaustion' with his administration. CNN correspondent John King reported from rural Iowa, highlighting the case of cattle rancher Shanen Ebersole from Kellerton, who voted for Trump but now strongly opposes his renewed push to acquire or annex Greenland, viewing it as unrelated to the 'America First' priorities she expected. She rated his performance a 3 out of 5, appreciating some improvements in border security and the economy but criticizing distractions like Greenland and trade policies favoring imports (e.g., low-tariff beef from Argentina). Ebersole indicated she is open to voting Democratic in the upcoming midterms, where Iowa will elect a governor, senator, and all four House members. item.title: Natural Methods to Slow Down Wrinkles and Support Skin Health
item.description:
Wrinkles are a natural part of aging, caused by reduced collagen and elastin production, leading to thinner, dehydrated skin. The article emphasizes that while chemical treatments and surgeries can offer results, they may cause irritation or long-term damage to the skin barrier. Instead, it promotes chemical-free approaches to maintain youthful, healthy skin through lifestyle changes and natural remedies.
Key lifestyle habits include staying well-hydrated by drinking plenty of water to keep skin elastic and glowing, eating a balanced diet rich in fiber, vitamins, and healthy fats to combat free radicals and support collagen production, getting sufficient quality sleep for skin cell renewal, and managing stress to prevent premature aging signs.

item.title: Far-right influencers sing controversial song at Miami nightclub, prompting firings and bans
item.description: A Miami nightclub, Vendome, faced criticism after a group of far-right influencers, including Nick Fuentes and Andrew Tate, were filmed singing along to Ye's song containing Nazi references. The event, which occurred on January 17, 2026, also featured some participants making Nazi salutes. The footage circulated widely on social media, sparking outrage from Jewish organizations, elected officials, and the public. The nightclub apologized, condemned antisemitism, and fired three employees while banning the personalities involved. They also implemented stricter content controls and management oversight to prevent similar incidents in the future. The song, which glorifies Hitler and has been banned on multiple streaming platforms, intensified concerns about far-right extremist influence and antisemitic rhetoric. item.title: Spanish Court of Auditors Report Highlights PCE's Reliance on Asset Sales to Offset Ongoing Losses (2017-2023)
item.description: According to the Spanish Tribunal de Cuentas' 2025 report on political party transparency and the PCE's own annual financial disclosures from 2017 to 2023, the Partido Comunista de España (PCE) has faced persistent financial challenges. Over this seven-year period, the party generated ordinary losses of approximately 1.29 million euros, which it offset by selling historical real estate assets worth 1.56 million euros, with the majority of sales (1.44 million euros) occurring between 2021 and 2023. Without these asset liquidations, the PCE would have recorded unsustainable deficits in its operations. Total ordinary income reached 13.16 million euros, with about 70% classified as private sources and 30% as direct public funding—contrasting sharply with major parties like the PP (83% public) and PSOE (68% public). item.title: Venezuela's Interim Government Under Delcy Rodríguez Pursues Pragmatic Economic Reforms and US Engagement After Maduro's Capture
item.description: Following the US military capture of Nicolás Maduro in early January 2026, Delcy Rodríguez assumed leadership as acting president of Venezuela and initiated a pragmatic economic and foreign policy adjustment. The government is reforming the Hydrocarbons Law to introduce Productive Participation Contracts, enabling foreign capital and technology—particularly from US firms like Chevron and ExxonMobil—to revitalize the oil sector and boost production. A key initial step was signing a contract for exporting liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), aligning with expressed US interests under Donald Trump in leading Venezuela's energy reactivation. item.description: Stephen McMennamy, a creative art director and photographer, has gained recognition for his ingenious #ComboPhotos series, where he masterfully combines two entirely unrelated photographs into one cohesive, surreal image. By carefully aligning shapes, forms, and perspectives, he creates seamless mashups that transform ordinary objects or scenes into something unexpectedly funny and visually striking. These works showcase an uncanny eye for visual harmony amid contrast, resulting in playful illusions that often evoke surprise and amusement. Featured via MyModernMet, the Moss and Fog article celebrates this ongoing project for its humorous punch and ability to deliver a welcome mental break from the stresses of contemporary life, including turbulent politics and international conflicts. item.description: On January 20, 2026, the European Parliament's main political groups announced a decision to postpone the ratification of a significant trade agreement with the United States. This deal, finalized in July 2025 after prolonged negotiations, aimed to reduce tariffs on US industrial goods entering the EU market and resolve ongoing trade disputes, including previous US impositions of 15% tariffs on EU exports. The delay serves as a symbolic yet impactful protest against President Donald Trump's recent threats to impose new tariffs on several EU member states—particularly France and Germany—if they do not support US acquisition of Greenland, an autonomous territory of Denmark. Lawmakers, including Valerie Hayer from the centrist Renew group, emphasized that suspending approval would pressure American businesses reliant on the European market, describing it as a 'powerful lever.' item.title: Newegg Offers 8% Discount on Southwest Gift Cards for One Day Only
item.description:
On January 20, 2026, Newegg launched a one-day promotion allowing customers to buy $500 Southwest Airlines gift cards for $460 by using the promo code SSF898. This limited-time offer effectively provided an 8% discount, with a purchase cap of ten cards per customer. The deal stood out because substantial discounts on Southwest gift cards have become uncommon in recent years, typically falling below the 10% mark once frequently seen in the travel rewards community.
Beyond the base savings, additional discounts or rewards were available by stacking credit card offers. item.title: Diez jugadoras del Txuri Urdin sufren intoxicación leve por monóxido de carbono tras partido en Puigcerdà
item.description: Durante el fin de semana del 25 y 26 de enero de 2026, se produjo una fuga de monóxido de carbono en el Poliesportiu de Puigcerdà (Girona), que afectó a varias personas durante una jornada con múltiples partidos de hockey sobre hielo. El incidente tuvo un impacto directo en el equipo femenino del Txuri Urdin, club donostiarra que disputaba un encuentro en la instalación. Diez jugadoras del equipo presentaron síntomas compatibles con una intoxicación leve por inhalación de este gas tóxico, como mareos, dolor de cabeza y malestar general. Estos síntomas aparecieron principalmente después de finalizar el partido, y fueron aumentando con el paso de las horas. Varias de las afectadas recibieron atención médica preventiva y seguimiento, aunque ninguna se encontraba en estado grave en el momento de la información inicial. item.title: La plataforma Libertad 6 de Zaragoza pide la liberación de dos jóvenes antes de las elecciones aragonesas
item.description: La plataforma ‘Libertad 6 de Zaragoza’ ha reclamado a las candidaturas que concurren a las elecciones aragonesas del 8 de febrero y que respaldan al Gobierno estatal que actúen de manera inmediata para lograr la liberación de los jóvenes antifascistas Daniel e Imad, encarcelados desde hace más de 650 días. Además, recuerdan que los jóvenes han perdido su derecho al voto en estas elecciones. La plataforma señala que no se han realizado avances para derogar la Ley Mordaza ni para impulsar reformas no punitivas del Código Penal, medidas que consideran necesarias para evitar la repetición de casos similares. item.title: La Asamblea Nacional francesa aprueba por amplia mayoría prohibir el acceso a redes sociales a menores de 15 años
item.description: La Asamblea Nacional de Francia aprobó este lunes 26 de enero de 2026 un proyecto de ley que prohíbe el acceso a las redes sociales a los menores de 15 años, así como el uso de teléfonos móviles en los institutos. La medida fue respaldada con 130 votos a favor y solo 21 en contra tras un debate extenso que se prolongó hasta la madrugada. Impulsada por el presidente Emmanuel Macron, quien la ha calificado como una defensa del cerebro de los niños frente a algoritmos adictivos de plataformas estadounidenses y chinas, la norma busca proteger la salud mental de los adolescentes ante riesgos como contenidos suicidas, automutilación, ciberacoso, comparación constante, alteraciones del sueño y reducción de actividad física, lectura y movimiento, según informes de la ANSES y argumentos de promotoras como la diputada Laure Miller, que criticó especialmente a TikTok. El ministro de Educación, Edouard Geffray, destacó los efectos positivos de prohibiciones previas de móviles en centros escolares

item.title: Denuncian graves deficiencias sanitarias y de bienestar animal en una macrogranja de codornices de Lleida certificada
item.description:
Una macrogranja de codornices situada en Juneda (Lleida) y vinculada al grupo Urgasa se encuentra bajo investigación tras una denuncia presentada por la entidad animalista ARDE ante la Fiscalía de Medio Ambiente de Catalunya. La denuncia se apoya en grabaciones realizadas en el interior de las instalaciones, donde se observan codornices hacinadas, presencia de excrementos acumulados, huevos en contacto con suciedad y cadáveres de aves en descomposición, así como animales vivos compartiendo espacio con restos orgánicos. Según ARDE, estas condiciones serían incompatibles con cualquier estándar mínimo de bienestar animal.
El caso resulta especialmente relevante porque la explotación dispone del sello de bienestar animal Welfair y del certificado Free to Fly, lo que ha generado dudas sobre la fiabilidad y el control real de estas certificaciones. Tras la publicación de la investigación, Welfair ha confirmado la realización de una auditoría interna no anunciada, aunque ha evitado pronuncia

item.title: Estados Unidos abandona la OMS sin saldar sus compromisos financieros y debilita la cooperación sanitaria global
item.description:
Estados Unidos ha dejado de ser oficialmente miembro de la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS) tras completar el periodo de retirada de un año previsto en una resolución conjunta del Congreso de 1948. La salida se produce sin que el país haya cumplido con sus obligaciones financieras, dejando impagos al menos 278 millones de dólares en cuotas correspondientes al periodo presupuestario 2024–2025, además de una cantidad indeterminada de fondos voluntarios prometidos.
Aunque el aviso formal de retirada se comunicó hace un año, la desvinculación práctica fue inmediata: la administración Trump cortó relaciones con la OMS desde el primer momento, justificando la decisión por su gestión de la pandemia de COVID-19, el sistema de cuotas y lo que considera un trato indulgente hacia China. A diferencia de su primer intento de salida durante el anterior mandato, que fue revocado por la administración Biden, esta vez el proceso ha culminado sin marcha atrás.

item.title: Países europeos acuerdan impulsar proyectos eólicos conjuntos en el Mar del Norte para reducir la dependencia energética de Rusia
item.description: El 26 de enero de 2026, durante la Cumbre del Mar del Norte celebrada en Hamburgo, líderes y ministros de energía de varios países europeos firmaron un acuerdo para acelerar el desarrollo de la energía eólica marina en esta zona. Los países participantes —Alemania, Bélgica, Dinamarca, Francia, Irlanda, Luxemburgo, Noruega, Países Bajos y Reino Unido— se comprometieron a crear una 'flota sin precedentes' de proyectos conjuntos de eólica offshore con una capacidad total de 100 GW, equivalente al consumo eléctrico de aproximadamente 100 millones de hogares. Aunque no se especificó un calendario concreto para este objetivo inicial, el pacto retoma metas anteriores más ambiciosas, como alcanzar 120 GW para 2030 y hasta 300 GW para 2050. El principal objetivo es fortalecer la independencia energética de Europa, especialmente tras la invasión rusa de Ucrania en 2022, que provocó una ruptura con el suministro de gas ruso y generó crisis de precios e inflación. item.title: China podría desplegar hasta 1.000 cazas furtivos J-20 para 2030, según expertos del RUSI
item.description: Según un informe reciente del Royal United Services Institute (RUSI), elaborado por el experto Justin Bronk, China está acelerando la producción de su caza furtivo de quinta generación J-20, con proyecciones que indican que la Fuerza Aérea del Ejército Popular de Liberación (PLAAF) podría contar con alrededor de 1.000 unidades operativas para 2030. Esta cifra incluye variantes como la J-20A y la biplaza J-20S. La producción anual ha alcanzado aproximadamente 120 aviones, pasando de unos 50 en 2020 a cerca de 300 a mediados de 2025. Este despliegue masivo, concentrado en una sola fuerza aérea, representa un cambio significativo en el equilibrio de poder aéreo en el Indopacífico, desafiando la superioridad tradicional de Estados Unidos, especialmente en escenarios como Taiwán y el Mar de la China Meridional. item.title: El Gregorio Marañón regulariza la compra de sensores médicos tras una década de contratos menores recurrentes
item.description:
El Hospital Universitario Gregorio Marañón, uno de los principales centros sanitarios de la Comunidad de Madrid, ha decidido licitar un contrato abierto para la compra de sensores de pulsioximetría después de haber recurrido durante más de una década a contratos menores adjudicados de forma reiterada a la empresa Medtronic. Entre 2014 y 2025, el hospital utilizó este procedimiento excepcional para adquirir miles de sensores desechables necesarios para la monitorización de pacientes en quirófanos, reanimación y cuidados intensivos, alegando la necesidad de evitar la interrupción de un servicio esencial.
La situación salió a la luz tras la actuación de Óscar Hernández, activista por la transparencia, que detectó un uso masivo y continuado de contratos menores con el mismo proveedor. Según los datos recopilados, el centro formalizó al menos 224 contratos menores entre 2017 y 2024 por un valor aproximado de 2,5 millones de euros solo para este material, además de otros cientos de contrato

item.title: EL TIMO DE COMPRAR UNA CASA DE PUEBLO
item.description: El vídeo explora los posibles problemas y trampas que pueden surgir al comprar una casa en un pueblo, incluyendo la complejidad de los trámites legales, las obligaciones con la comunidad, el estado real de la propiedad, los costos ocultos de mantenimiento y restauración, y la dificultad de encontrar inquilinos o compradores en zonas rurales.

item.title: El hongo Lanmaoa asiatica y las alucinaciones liliputienses en Yunnan: investigación científica en marcha
item.description:
En la provincia de Yunnan, China, cientos de personas acuden cada año a hospitales tras consumir el hongo Lanmaoa asiatica sin cocinarlo adecuadamente. Este hongo, popular por su sabor umami y consumido en mercados y restaurantes durante la temporada de junio a agosto, provoca alucinaciones muy específicas: visiones de figuras diminutas, como duendes o humanos pequeños, que se mueven por las paredes, trepan por los muebles o pasan bajo las puertas. Estas 'alucinaciones liliputienses', término psiquiátrico inspirado en Los viajes de Gulliver, son sorprendentemente consistentes entre los afectados y pueden durar entre 12 y 24 horas, llegando incluso a requerir hospitalización prolongada.
El investigador Colin Domnauer, de la Universidad de Utah, ha estudiado esta especie durante años. En 2023 visitó Yunnan, confirmó su identidad mediante secuenciación genética y encontró que extractos del hongo alteran el comportamiento de ratones de forma similar a los efectos en humanos.
